definition: Beijing opera/CL:齣|出[chu1]
abbr. for Beijing/surname Jing/Jing ethnic minority
capital city of a country/big/algebraic term for a large number (old)/artificial mound (old)
trick/drama/play/show/CL:齣|出[chu1],場|场[chang3],臺|台[tai2]

sentences.english: He can't sing a song well, let alone Beijing Opera.
sentences.chinese: 他連一首歌曲都唱不好，更不用說唱京戲了。

sentences.english: During the Festival of Arts, I went to see a Beijing opera put up by a Shanghai troupe.
sentences.chinese: 藝術節的時候，我看了一出由上海某劇團演的京戲。

sentences.english: But now even the King of Chu is on his knees begging for mercy, can Peking opera survive this indignity?
sentences.chinese: 連楚霸王都跪下來求饒了，京戲能不亡嗎？

sentences.english: Beijing Opera () () () listening to . It is the pride of China.
sentences.chinese: 京戲很值得聽，它是神州的驕傲。

sentences.english: Do you know something about chinese opera?

definition: ballad tune in southern dialects, usually to sanxian 三弦 or pipa 琵琶 accompaniment
Henan opera
Huangmei opera (local opera of Anhui)
keyboard instrument (piano, organ etc)
genre of song-and-dance duet popular in northeast China
lit. dragon soaring and tiger leaping (idiom)/fig. prosperous and bustling/vigorous and active
a form of theatrical double act in which one performer speaks or sings while the other, in front, pretends to be doing the speaking or singing/double reed (as in an oboe or bassoon)
sequel/continuation of a book
female warrior role in Chinese opera
folk story/folktale
Ma Sanli (1914-2003), Chinese comedian
opera highlights performed as independent pieces
vivid and colorful (idiom); true to life/lively and realistic
to churn out large quantities without regard for quality (idiom); rough and slipshod work
to notate music/to write a score
to split heaven and earth apart (idiom); refers to the Pangu 盤古|盘古[Pan2 gu3] creation myth
